body:
After executing the command for remote server `mlflow server --file-store /tmp/MLFlow/ -h 0.0.0.0` , can you check if you are able to access the mlflow UI through the tracking server url. 

This should be the same url that you set as the tracking uri

Hi, I have same error. I try to use MLflow Project. MLflow: 0.7.0 Python: 3.6.3 random_forest_sample/learning_job.py ``` #!/usr/bin/python3 import sklearn.datasets from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifier from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split import mlflow import mlflow.sklearn import sys n_estimators = int(sys.argv[1]) if len(sys.argv) > 1 else 10 max_depth = int(sys.argv[2]) if len(sys.argv) > 2 else 5 random_state = int(sys.argv[3]) if len(sys.argv) > 3 else 71 iris = sklearn.datasets.load_iris() X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(iris.data, iris.target, test_size=0.3, random_state=random_state) model = RandomForestClassifier(n_estimators=n_estimators, max_depth=max_depth, random_state=random_state) model.fit(X_train, y_train) print(model.predict(X_test)) score = model.score(X_test, y_test) mlflow.set_tracking_uri('http://10.2.2.110:5000') mlflow.start_run() mlflow.log_param("n_estimatores", n_estimators) mlflow.log_param("max_depth", max_depth) mlflow.log_param("random_state", random_state) mlflow.log_metric("score", score) mlflow.sklearn.log_model(model, "ml_models") mlflow.end_run() ``` random_forest_sample/MLproject ``` name: ProjectA conda_env: conda.yaml entry_points: main: parameters: n_estimators: {type: float, default: 10} max_depth: {type: float, default: 5} random_state: {type: float, default: 71} command: "python learning_job.py {n_estimators} {max_depth} {random_state}" ``` random_forest_sample/conda.yaml ``` name: ProjectA channels: - defaults dependencies: - python=3.6.3 - numpy=1.14.5 - pandas=0.23.3 - scikit-learn=0.19.2 - pip: - mlflow ``` At remote server, the mlflow tracking server is executed. ``` $ mlflow server --file-store /mlflow --port 5000 --host 0.0.0.0 ``` I can access to web ui. I can get success to execute python directly. ``` $ python random_forest_sample/learning_job.py ``` But, When I use mlproject run, I got failure.. ``` $ mlflow run random_forest_sample -P n_estimators=15 -P max_depth=2 -P random_state=71 === Created directory /tmp/tmp0w4bepel for downloading remote URIs passed to arguments of type 'path' === === Running command 'source activate mlflow-15279de32928f0ea0ae0ce4eb82ef3271fcbd75f && python learning_job.py 15 2 71' in run with ID '2152f0d9c96b4a82a06a7f0cf4b1d71b' === [2 0 1 1 1 1 0 2 2 2 2 0 0 1 0 0 2 1 1 1 1 0 1 1 1 2 2 2 2 2 2 0 0 2 0 1 1 0 0 0 1 1 0 1 1] API request to http://10.2.2.110:5000/api/2.0/preview/mlflow/runs/get failed with code 500 != 200, retrying up to 2 more times. API response body: 500 Internal Server Error

Internal Server Error

The server encountered an internal error and was unable to complete your request. Either the server is overloaded or there is an error in the application.

API request to http://10.2.2.110:5000/api/2.0/preview/mlflow/runs/get failed with code 500 != 200, retrying up to 1 more times. API response body: 500 Internal Server Error

Internal Server Error

The server encountered an internal error and was unable to complete your request. Either the server is overloaded or there is an error in the application.

API request to http://10.2.2.110:5000/api/2.0/preview/mlflow/runs/get failed with code 500 != 200, retrying up to 0 more times. API response body: 500 Internal Server Error

Internal Server Error

The server encountered an internal error and was unable to complete your request. Either the server is overloaded or there is an error in the application.

Are you able to access `http://10.2.2.110:5000` from browser 

From the logs  it looks there is some issue while connecting to server
`mlflow.exceptions.MlflowException: API request to http://10.2.2.110:5000/api/2.0/preview/mlflow/runs/get failed to return code 200 after 3 tries`

> After executing the command for remote server `mlflow server --file-store /tmp/MLFlow/ -h 0.0.0.0` , can you check if you are able to access the mlflow UI through the tracking server url.
> 
> This should be the same url that you set as the tracking uri

I can access the mlflow UI and log_param, log_metric, but i can not put .txt to remote server

Thank you for reply.

Yes, I can connect to Tracking server web ui from browser and from curl command in cli.
And when I execute this learning_job.py script with python command, tracking info is registered correctly.
So, I think that this python code can access to tracking server uri.

Furthermore, I executed tracking server and ml project run at the same server, but "mlflow run" received the same error...
may be somehting tied to Permissions/Rights? may you choose something other than /tmp for the server?

Running into the same issue here, when trying to `mlflow.sklearn.log_model()`. I've started my remote tracking server with `--file-store /tmp/mlruns --default-artifact-root /tmp/artifacts` though I can see the `.pkl` file being created on my **local machine**, under `/tmp/`.

Try the following in your code:
`print(mlflow.get_artifact_uri())`

Output:
`/tmp/artifacts/0/c6609d80cb78431a84ce846761106145/artifacts`

Apologies for the delayed response - MLflow doesn't currently support logging artifacts to the local filesystem of a remote tracking server. This is because artifacts are actually written by the client, which just obtains an artifact location to write to from the tracking server. Instead, we recommend launching your tracking server with ``--default-artifact-root`` set to an artifact location accessible to both the tracking server & the client, e.g. an S3 bucket URI. See the [tracking docs](https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/tracking.html#storage) and [this SO post](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/52331254/how-to-store-artifacts-on-a-server-running-mlflow) for more information.

Also one gotcha worth noting from the SO post:

> Note that the server uses ``--default-artifact-root`` only when assigning artifact roots to newly-created experiments - runs created under existing experiments will use an artifact root directory under the existing experiment's artifact root.

So you'll need to create a new experiment for the artifact root change to take place. Thanks all for discussing this, it's come up a few times - I'd suggest these simple changes to make using `log_artifact` smoother:

* Log a warning when `mlflow server` is run without ``--default-artifact-root`` (and eventually, require `--default-artifact-root`)
* Log the artifact path being used when `log_artifact` is called.

The docs here (https://www.mlflow.org/docs/latest/tracking.html#amazon-s3) state that you can use a minio server for logging. If I'm running the server in a docker container, should I be setting the environment variable in the container? Can I do this through the python api?

@bertomartin sorry for the super late response, yep you should be setting the environment variable in the container. BTW, nowadays for questions of this sort we recommend asking in https://stackoverflow.com/tags/mlflow/

As per @smurching 's [comment above](https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/issues/572#issuecomment-427718078), support for remote logging is supported through `--default-artifact-root`. Refer [docs](https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/tracking.html#artifact-stores) for for support for various type of artifact store types.

> As per @smurching 's [comment above](https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/issues/572#issuecomment-427718078), support for remote logging is supported through `--default-artifact-root`. Refer [docs](https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/tracking.html#artifact-stores) for for support for various type of artifact store types.

I'd argue, that there is still no support for uploading artifacts to server side. Like for instance it is available in H2O, which uses separate menu options and/or API functions for remote and local actions (download / upload vs import / save). NFS is not remote if it has to be mounted locally on the client side... One needs yet another server apart from `mlflow server` or else our most important artifacts will be dispersed in local users folders, siloed, passworded, or manually deleted as the `./mflow` folder is not hidden...

Compared to H2O, where one can upload data to a training server and then download trained models from the server, even using a browser, without any scripting (and without having to set up another server such as NFS), remote storage of artifacts in MLflow Tracking is non-existent.

> remote storage of artifacts in MLflow Tracking is non-existent.

Is it still true?

> > remote storage of artifacts in MLflow Tracking is non-existent.
> 
> Is it still true?

Yes, in the sense that an object storage server like minio is needed to perform the storage of artifacts, which must be first saved locally to a temporary folder and then uploaded by the mlflow python client directly to the s3 endpoint. To provide universal storage support neither client nor server have anything to do with minio client (a separate package) or server (a minio container is required as a server and boto3 package dependencies are on both sides: the python client system and the mlflow container). This is a completely opposite design paradigm than in case of H2O: loose coupling / microservices architecture as opposed to bundling all features into a monolithic application. I'm running 4 extra containers to host mlflow on prem (and that's just on server side, not counting python and R client containers), including nginx as a reverse proxy purely for authentication. Compare and contrast with H20, which any 20-year old intern with some basic R could put up and use within minutes... but at the cost of very strict version checking (no official support for backward compatibility of the client with previous versions of the server causes H2O to be really upgrade resistant in production systems and a pain to maintain even in dev environments, where the need to pin H2O at an old version creates dependencies problems for unpinned packages).
Hi, is there any update for this so far? Can we log artifacts on server now?
Is there a feature request to support logging artifacts on a remove mlflow server? This seems to me an obvious feature that many people would like to have.

# Logging Plugin
---

Please help me with creating a custom plugin to log the current running notebook and also log .py to a remote server.
You can bypass this issue by using volumes if working with docker containers.

> 
> 
> You can bypass this issue by using volumes if working with docker containers.

Can you elaborate? I couldn't manage to run a remote server and log artefacts to it. Instead, the client (Python MLflow API) is trying to write to the client's local storage with the **path I defined in a docker container**.

My `docker-compose.yml` looks like:
```docker-compose
services:
    db:
        <PostgreSQL set-up>
    web:
        build: mlflow
        restart: always
        image: mlflow_server
        container_name: mlflow_server
        ports:
            - "5000":"5000"
        depends_on:
            - db
        volumes:
            - ./mlruns:/var/lib/mlflow/mlruns
        command: "mlflow server
                           --backend-store-url postgresql://...
                           --default-artifact-root /var/lib/mlflow/mlruns
                           --host 0.0.0.0"
```
Even if I put `file://<remote's IP>/var/lib/mlflow/mlruns` it still tries to write artifacts to the client's `/var/lib/mlflow/mlruns` (for which it doesn't have access).

Note: I have a simple `Dockerfile` in `<workdir>/mlflow/mlflow`.

This is how it works on my local machine as NFS variant. The clients artifacts folder has to be the same as the folder of the mlflow container. This is achieved by a volume. Additionally you have to change the command property to `--default-artifact-root /mlflow/` since it is the property that is returned by the get_artifact_url function in python.

```
services:
  dsplatform-postgres:
    build: ./postgres
    environment:
      POSTGRES_USER: "${POSTGRES_USER}"
      POSTGRES_PASSWORD: "${POSTGRES_PASSWORD}"
      POSTGRES_DB: "${POSTGRES_DB}"
      POSTGRES_INITDB_ARGS: "--encoding=UTF-8"
    ports:
      - 5432:5432
    volumes:
      - /postgres/data:/var/lib/postgresql/data
    restart: always
  dsplatform-mlflow:
    build: ./mlflow
    ports:
      - 5000:5000
    volumes:
      - ./artifacts/:/mlflow
      - /opt/mlflow/scripts
    restart: always
    depends_on:
      - dsplatform-postgres
  dsplatform-jupyter:
    image: jupyter/base-notebook:python-3.8.5
    environment:
      PASSWORD: "${JUPYTER_PASSWORD}"
    ports:
      - 8888:8888
    volumes:
      - ./artifacts/:/mlflow
    restart: always
```

Finally I also got it running on my server with a jupyter instance in a separate compose. But it only works with mlflow as folder name.
Having the same problem using mlflow on a simple AWS EC2 instance. Hope this will be fixed. In the meantime I will try to connect an S3 storage to my EC2 instance.

> Is there a feature request to support logging artifacts on a remove mlflow server? This seems to me an obvious feature that many people would like to have.

Yeah. Gotta agree... I hardly see the purpose of MLflow beyond a per-experiment key-value store without this feature. You'd pretty much be better off writing your own with FastAPI or something.
